qas.question: According to Bastian, what did he believe all human societies shared?
What was the name of the person argued for "The psychic unity of mankind"?
Who trained under Bastian's ideas on culture?
What did Adolf Bastian believe all human societies ignored?
Who argued for "The psychic separation of mankind"?
Who first taught Bastian's ideas on culture?
What view did not have a paved way for modern understanding?

context: In 1860, <a1_0><b4_0>Adolf Bastian<b4_0/><a1_0/> (1826–1905) argued for "the psychic unity of mankind". He proposed that a scientific comparison of all human societies would reveal that distinct worldviews consisted of the same basic elements. According to Bastian, all human societies share a set of "<a0_0><b3_0>elementary ideas<b3_0/><a0_0/>" (Elementargedanken); different cultures, or different "folk ideas" (<b6_0>Völkergedanken<b6_0/>), are local modifications of the elementary ideas. This view paved the way for the modern understanding of <b7_0>culture<b7_0/>. <a2_0><b5_0>Franz Boas<b5_0/><a2_0/> (1858–1942) was trained in this tradition, and he brought it with him when he left Germany for the United States.
